subject: RE: [junit] debuggers
msgSnippet: There is no question that once Other People s Code is involved, you need tracing/logging. You don t have the chance to test their stuff, so you can t trust it

There is no question that once Other People's Code is involved, you need tr=
acing/logging. You don't have the chance to test their stuff, so you can't =
trust it in production, even though I counsel in favor of trusting it durin=
g development.

So said  Michael Silverstein  on  3/14/2003 ---------------=
-----

>Good observation about using deduction to locate points of failure.=
 Not
>to be picky, I tend to view statements about the possibility of never=

>needing to trace code based on small scale examples, as similar to
>concl=
uding that you don't need sight to drive on highways because of
>success tr=
aversing one's driveway with one's eyes closed. I agree with
>Steven below =
that the strategy you take depends on your context.
>Fine-grained test case=
s may reduce the need for tracing code with
>debuggers but with any suffici=
ently complex application, especially one
>that interacts with questionably=
 documented 3rd party or system APIs, a
>debugger will at some point become=
 invaluable in determining the cause
>of failure.
>
>----------------------=
-------
>Mike Silverstein
>SilverMark, Inc.
>The Object Testing Company
>ww=
w.javatesting.com
>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: J. B. Rainsberge=
r [mailto:jbrains@...] 
>> 
>> I completed my first professional Rub=
y project a week ago. It 
>> was nothing big: three weeks of Saturdays -- b=
ut it was my 
>> first professional project with a dynamically-typed langua=
ge 
>> with no type checker. This caused me some problems, just 
>> because=
 I'm not used to it. I usually say, "The compiler just 
>> stops me from ma=
king mistakes that I don't make anyway." I 
>> suppose that's not quite rig=
ht for me.
>> 
>> Anyhow, that's just a lead-in to my comment. In many case=
s, I 
>> would have either an unexpected 'nil' value, or an object 
>> that=
 doesn't understand an expected message. My first 
>> instinct is to get in=
 there with "p this" and "p that"... 
>> then I thought of this: if I have =
a 'nil' object over here, 
>> then there must be a bug over there... and wh=
en I started 
>> writing tests checking that results are non-nil over there=
, I 
>> no longer needed to trace my code.
>> 
>> I'm still learning.
>> 
>=
> So said steven.hale@... on 3/13/2003 --------------------
>> 
>> My d=
ebugging habits are usually something like this:
>> 
>> 1. Read the error m=
essage (if there is one)
>> 2. Think
>> 3. Read the log
>> 4. Think
>> 5. W=
rite a unit test
>> 6. Launch the debugger
>> 
>> Since adopting junit (2 -=
3 years ago) I can honestly say I've 
>> not yet been forced down to level =
6! I try to encourage 
>> programmers in my team not to start at 6 first.
>=
> 
>> Judging by the varied responses there's clearly a whole range 
>> of =
other successful strategies - maybe it's related to the 
>> type of applica=
tion being programmed.
>> 
>> Steven
>> 
>
>>
